revision.text:
{{pp-protected|reason=Persistent [[WP:Disruptive editing|disruptive editing]]: persistent addition of spam|small=yes}} {{See also|List of mergers and acquisitions by Google}} {{update|date=March 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} [[File:Google 2015 logo.svg|thumb|right|240px|Google's logo since September 2015.]]
The following is a list of products and services provided by [[Google]].
== Web-based products ==
=== Search tools === * [[Google Search]] is a web search engine and [[Google]]'s core product. It receives over 3 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] search queries per day. Google also offers regional search by its 189 regional level domains. **[[Google Hummingbird|Hummingbird]] – Expanded query analysis. For example, if you search for 'best pie place in Seattle' Google will also search for 'best pie restaurant in Seattle'. ** [[PageRank]] – link analysis algorithm. ** [[Google search#Search results|Snapshots]] – mechanism that indexes [[PDF]]s, Word documents, and more. ** [[Google search#Functionality|Google Search functionality]] – includes [[Boolean logic]]al operators, [[Wildcard character|wildcards]], and more, to help users refine their searches. ** [[Google search#International|Multiple languages]] – process information in many languages. ** [[Experimental Search]] Options for testing new interfaces while searching with Google, including Timeline views and keyboard shortcuts. * [[Google Alerts]] – email notification service that sends alerts based on chosen search terms, whenever it finds new results. Alerts include web results, [[Google Groups|Groups]] results news and video.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hill|first1=Kashmir|title='Google Alerts' Are Broken|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kashmirhill/2013/07/30/google-alerts-are-broken/#c7a9be25abd5|website=Forbes.com|accessdate=October 10, 2016|date=July 30, 2013}}</ref> * [[Google Assistant]] – voice-based Search Service and AI Assistant. It debuted in May 2016. * [[Google Books]] (formerly Print) – search engine for the full text of printed books. The content that is displayed depends on arrangements with publishers, ranging from short extracts to entire books. * [[Google Custom Search]] – create a customized search experience for a website. Renamed from Google Co-op, which in turn replaced Google Free Search. * [[Google Dictionary]] – search definitions for words and phrases * [[Google Dataset Search]] – search data repositories and local and national government websites for datasets.<ref>{{cite web |last1= Noy |first1=Natasha |title=Making it easier to discover datasets |url= https://www.blog.google/products/search/making-it-easier-discover-datasets/ |publisher= Google |accessdate= September 10, 2018 |date= September 5, 2018}}</ref> * [[Google Finance]] – searchable US business news, opinion and financial data. Features include company-specific pages, blog search, interactive charts, executives information, discussion groups and a portfolio. * [[Google Groups]] – web and email discussion service and [[Usenet]] archive. Users can join a group, make a group, publish posts, track favorite topics, write a set of group web pages updatable by members and share group files. * [[Google Hotel Finder]] – search for hotels, including check-in and check-out dates.<ref>{{cite web|title=What is Google Hotel Finder?|url=https://support.google.com/hotelfinder?hl=en|publisher=Google|accessdate=November 7, 2012}}</ref> * [[Google Flights]] – search for flights from many airlines to many destinations, offering tools such as price comparisons and travel recommendations.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to search and book flights|url=https://support.google.com/flights/?hl=en|publisher=Google|accessdate=July 29, 2014}}</ref> * [[Google Image Search]] – search images, with results based on the file name of the image, the link text pointing to the image and text adjacent to the image. Search based on an uploaded image. * [[Google Translate|Language Tools]] – Collection of linguistic applications, including one that allows users to translate text or web pages from one language to another, and another that allows searching in web pages located in a specific country or written in a specific language. * [[Life Search]] ([[Google China]]) – Search engine tailored towards everyday needs, such as train times, recipes and housing. * [[Google News]] – automated [[news]] compilation service and search engine for news for more than 20 languages. While the selection of news stories is fully automated, the sites are selected by human editors. * [[Google Patent Search]] – search engine to search through millions of [[patents]], each result with its own page, including drawings, claims and citations. * [[Google Recipe View]] – search results show only recipes, and shows ratings, ingredients and pictures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2011/02/slice-and-dice-your-recipe-search.html|title=Official Google Blog: Slice and dice your recipe search results|work=Official Google Blog}}</ref> * [[Google Scholar]] – search the full text of scholarly literature across an array of publishing formats and scholarly fields. Includes virtually all peer-reviewed journals. * [[Google Shopping]] (was Google Product Search and Froogle): search online stores, including auctions, for products.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://googlecommerce.blogspot.com/2012/05/building-better-shopping-experience.html|title=Google Commerce: Building a better shopping experience|work=Google Commerce Blog|date=May 31, 2012}}</ref> * Suggest{{anchor|Suggest}} – [[Autocomplete|auto-completion]] in search results while typing to give popular searches. * [[Google Video]]<nowiki/> – video search engine. Google's video partnerships include agreements with [[CBS]], [[NHL]] and the [[NBA]]. It searches videos posted on YouTube, Metacafe, DailyMotion, and other popular video hosting sites.<ref>{{cite web|title=Google to close five services|url=http://www.menafn.com/menafn/1093529726/Google-to-close-five-services|website=MENAFN.COM|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120802001321/http://www.menafn.com/menafn/1093529726/Google-to-close-five-services|archivedate=August 2, 2012|date=July 4, 2012}}</ref> * [[Google Web History]] (was Google Search History, [[Personalized Search]]) – web page tracking, which records Google searches, web pages, images, videos, music and other data. It includes bookmarks, search trends and item recommendations. Google released Search History in April 2005, when it began to record browsing history,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2005/04/from-lost-to-found.html |title=From lost to found |last=Shah |first=Avni |work=Google Blog |date=April 20, 2005}}</ref> expanding and renaming the service to Web History in April 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2007/04/your-slice-of-web.html |title=Your slice of the web |last=Shodjai |first=Payam |work=Google Blog |date=April 19, 2007}}</ref> * [[Knowledge Graph]] – a knowledge base used to enhance search results with semantic information gathered from several sources. * [[Shortcuts]]{{dn|date=October 2018}} – various, simple Google services available directly from [[Google Search]] like information about weather, a calculator, sport scores, dictionary etc. * [[Zagat]] – a source of consumer survey-based information for restaurants and other leisure activities.
=== Advertising services === * [[AdMob]] – mobile advertising network<ref name=Mashable>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2009/11/09/google-acquires-admob/|title=Facts about Google's acquisition of AdMob|accessdate=November 9, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091110214653/http://mashable.com/2009/11/09/google-acquires-admob/| archivedate=November 10, 2009 | deadurl= no}}</ref> that offers advertising solutions for [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]] and [[Windows Phone]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://developers.google.com/mobile-ads-sdk/download|title=Mobile Ads SDK|website=Google Developers|publisher=Google|accessdate=August 26, 2014}}</ref> * [[Google AdSense]] – contextual advertising solution to web publishers that delivers text-based Google Ads ads that are relevant to site content pages. *[[Google AdWords|Google Ads]] – selects and displays ads in the Sponsored Links section next to search results. *[[Google Ad Grants]] – in-kind donation program awarding free AdWords advertising to select charitable organizations. *[[Google Adwords Express|Adwords Express]] – local online advertising * [[Google Certification Program]] – AdWords partner certification program, providing AdWords qualifications to agencies that pass exams and other criteria. Replaced Google Advertising Professionals in April 2010. * [[DoubleClick]] – ad management and ad serving technology foundation for buyers, creators and sellers of digital media. * [[DoubleClick for Publishers by Google]] – drives direct sales revenue and maximizes yield on non-guaranteed inventory. * [[Google Display Planner]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://support.google.com/adplanner/answer/3310841?hl=en|title=Ad Planner has been discontinued|work=google.com}}</ref> *[[Google Think Insights]]
=== Communication and publishing tools === * [[Google Cultural Institute]] * [[Google Art Project]] * [[FeedBurner]] – [[news feed]] management services, including feed traffic analysis and advertising facilities. * [[Google 3D Warehouse]] – online service that hosts [[3D computer graphics|3D]] models of existing objects, locations (including buildings) and vehicles created in [[SketchUp|Google SketchUp]]. Models can be downloaded into Google Sketch-up by other users or [[Google Earth]]. * [[G Suite]] – service for businesses, enterprise, and education providing independently customizable versions of several Google products under a custom [[domain name]]. Services included are [[Gmail]], [[Google Hangouts]], [[Google Calendar]], [[Google Docs]], [[Google Sheets]], [[Google Forms]], [[Google Slides]], [[Google Sites]], [[Google Contacts]] and [[Google Groups]]. * [[Google Hire]] - human resources hiring tool. Provides a system for employers to collect applications and search for job candidates.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hire, a Recruiting App from Google|url=https://hire.google.com/|website=Hire|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> * [[Blogger (service)|Blogger]] – [[weblog]] publishing tool. Users can create custom, [[web hosting|hosted]] blogs with features such as photo publishing, comments, group blogs, blogger profiles and mobile-based posting with little technical knowledge. * [[Google Bookmarks]] – free online bookmark storage service<ref>[https://www.google.com/support/toolbar/bin/answer.py?answer=43305&topic=15364&hl=en Bookmarks] ''Google help''</ref> * [[Boutiques.com]] – personalized shopping to find/discover fashion goods<ref>{{cite web|last=Albanesius |first=Chloe |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2393447,00.asp |title=Google Overhauls Product Search, Ditches Boutiques.com |publisher=PCMag.com |date=September 23, 2011 |accessdate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> * [[Google Business Solutions]] – collection of services offered by Google directed at webmasters and businesses.<ref name="Google Business Solutions Website">{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/services/|title=Google Business Solutions|publisher=Google|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> Components: [[Feedburner]], [[Google AdWords]], [[Google AdSense]], [[Google Analytics]], Google Enterprise Search solutions, [[G Suite]], [[Google Checkout]], [[Google Local Business Center]], Google Merchant Center, Google Trusted Stores, [[Postini]], Google Webmaster Central, [[Google Ad Manager]], Google Maps and Earth Solutions, [[Google Website Optimizer]] * [[Google Calendar]] – online [[calendar]] with [[Gmail]] integration, calendar sharing and a "quick add" function to create events using natural language. It is similar to those offered by [[Yahoo!]] and [[Windows Live]]. * [[Google Charts]] - interactive, Web-based chart image generation from user-supplied JavaScript. * [[Google Docs]] – document, spreadsheet, drawing, survey and presentation application, with document collaboration and publishing capabilities. * [[Google Domains]] — domain registration service, with website publishing partners. * [[Google Drive]] – online backup service and storage space. * [[Google Hangouts]] – an instant messaging and video chat platform *[[Gmail]] (also termed Google Mail) – IMAP and POP email service, known for its abundant storage, intuitive search-based interface and elasticity. * [[Google Inbox]] – email app for Android, iOS and web platforms that organizes emails and automates to-do lists using email content * [[Google URL Shortener]] – [[URL shortening|URL shortener]] for Google and non-Google websites. Also referred to as Goo.gl. * [[Google Keep]] – a [[note-taking]] service similar to [[Evernote]]. * [[Google Play Music]] - upload up to 50,000 songs for free for cloud media access. * [[Google+]] – [[social networking service]]. *[[Poly (website)|Poly]] – creators can browse, share and download [[3D modeling|3D models]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://blog.google/products/google-VR/poly-browse-discover-and-download-3d-objects-and-scenes/|title=Poly: Browse, discover and download 3D objects and scenes|author=Andrea Zvinakis|date=November 1, 2017|work=Google|access-date=November 1, 2017|language=en}}</ref> *[[Google profile]] – control how a user appears and presents themselves on Google products * [[Google Sites]] (formerly Jotspot) – a [[wiki]]- and [[web page]]-creation tool both for personal and corporate use. * [[SMS Channels]] (Google India only) – create and subscribe to channels over SMS. Channels can be based on [[RSS]] feeds. * [[Speak To Tweet]] – [[telephone]] service created in collaboration with [[Twitter]] and SayNow allowing users to phone a specific number and leave a [[voicemail]]; a tweet is automatically posted on Twitter with a link to the voice message stored on Google's SayNow. * [[Google Voice]] (United States only) – [[Voice over IP|VoIP]] system. Google Voice provides a phone number but is not the last mile provider. It includes a follow-me service that lets users forward their Google voice phone number to simultaneously ring up to 6 phone numbers. It also features a unified [[voice mail]] service, SMS and free outgoing calls via Google's "click2call" and 3rd party dialers. * [[Google Fonts]] – interactive directory of hosted web font-API's. * [[YouTube]] – [[video sharing]] service that lets users upload, view and share [[video clip]]s. * [[Google Ventures]] – venture-capital fund * [[Google Classroom]] – [[content management system]] for schools that aids in distribution and grading of assignments and providing in-class communication. * [[Google Cloud Platform|Google Cloud]] Search - smart search engine that allows [[G Suite]] business customers to search across G Suite products.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/02/07/google-debuts-cloud-search-a-smart-search-engine-for-g-suite-customers/|title=Google debuts Cloud Search, a smart search engine for G Suite customers|publisher=TechCrunch|author=Sarah Perez|date=February 7, 2017|access-date=February 8, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cio.com/article/3167185/cloud-computing/google-cloud-search-helps-enterprise-users-find-data-quickly.html|title=Google Cloud Search helps enterprise users find data quickly|publisher=CIO|author=Blair Hanley Frank |date=February 7, 2017|access-date=February 8, 2017}}</ref>
== Development tools == * [[Google App Engine]] – write and run web applications. * [[Google Developers]] (was Google Code) – [[Open-source software|open source]] code and lists of [[API]] services. Provides project hosting for [[free and open source software]]. * [[Dart (programming language)|Dart]] – structured web programming language * [[Flutter (software)|Flutter]] – mobile cross platform development tool for iOS and Android * [[Go (programming language)]] – compiled, concurrent programming language * [[OpenSocial]] – APIs for building social applications on many websites. * [[Google PageSpeed Tools]] – optimize webpage performance * [[Google Web Toolkit]] – open source Java software development framework that allows web developers to create Ajax applications in Java. * [[Google Search Console]] Sitemap – submission and analysis for the [[Sitemaps]] protocol. * [[Google Translator Toolkit|Translator Toolkit]] – collaborative translation tool
=== Security tools === * [[reCAPTCHA]] – a user-dialogue system used to prevent bots from accessing websites. * [[Google Safe Browsing]] – blacklist service for web resources that contain malware or phishing content. * [[Titan Security Key]] - a [[security token]].
=== Map-related products === * [[Google Maps]] – mapping service that indexes streets and displays satellite and street-level imagery, providing directions and local business search **[[Google Street View]] ** Google Street View Inside Trusted – 360°, interactive tour.<ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212011759/https://maps.google.com/maps/about/partners/businessview |url=https://maps.google.com/maps/about/partners/businessview/ |title=Google Maps Business Photos |archivedate= February 12, 2015}}</ref> Walk around, explore and interact with a business using Street View technology. * [[Google My Maps]] – social custom map making tool based on Google Maps * Google Maps Gallery – collection of data and historic maps * [[Google Mars]] – imagery of Mars using the Google Maps interface. Elevation, visible imagery and infrared imagery can be shown. * [[Google Moon]] – NASA imagery of the moon through the Google Maps interface * [[Google Sky]] – view planets, stars and galaxies * [[Google Transit]] – public transport trip planning through the [[Google Maps]] interface * [[Google Santa Tracker]] – track [[Santa Claus]] on [[Christmas Eve]] * [[Zygote Body]] – 3D [[anatomy|anatomical]] model of [[human body]] * Build with Chrome – an initiative between [[Lego]] and Google to build the world using Lego.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.buildwithchrome.com/about|title = About Build With Chrome|date = |accessdate=March 12, 2015|website = Build with Chrome|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> *[[Google Maps pin#Other uses by Google|Smarty Pins]] – geographical trivia game that features the Google Maps pin
=== Statistical tools === * [[Google Analytics]] – traffic statistics generator for defined websites, with AdWords integration. Webmasters can optimize ad campaigns, based on the statistics. Analytics are based on the [[Urchin (software)|Urchin software]]. * [[Google Consumer Surveys]] – market research tool similar to [[Survata]]. * [[Google Correlate]] – search patterns relating to real world trends. * [[Freebase]] - open, [[Creative Commons|creative commons]], attribution licensed collection of structured data, and a Freebase platform for accessing and manipulating that data via the Freebase [[API]]. * [[Google Fusion Tables]] – gather and visualize arbitrary data * [[Google Ngram Viewer]] – chart year-by-year frequencies of any set of comma-delimited strings in Google's text corpora. * [[Google Public Data Explorer]] – public data and forecasts from international organizations and academic institutions including the World Bank, [[OECD]], [[Eurostat]] and the University of Denver * [[TensorFlow]] - [[Machine learning|Machine Learning]] service that simplifies designing neural networks in an easier and more visible fashion * [[Google Trends]] – graphing application for Web Search statistics, showing the popularity of particular search terms over time. Multiple terms can be shown at once. Results can be displayed by city, region or language. Related news stories are shown. Has "Google Trends for Websites" sub-section that shows popularity of websites over time. *[[Google Activity Report]] – monthly report including statistics about a user's Google usage, such as sign-in, third party authentication changes, Gmail usage, calendar, search history and YouTube.
== Operating systems == * [[Android (operating system)|Android]] – Linux-based operating system for mobile devices such as smartphones and tablet computers * [[Chrome OS]] – Linux-based operating system for web applications<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/intl/en/chrome/devices/chromebox.html |title=Samsung Chromebox |publisher=Google |accessdate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> * [[Wear OS]] – version of Google's Android operating system designed for smartwatches and other wearable items. * [[Android Auto]] – version of Android made for automobiles by Google with the help of the [[Open Automotive Alliance]] * [[Google TV]] – it was smart TV interface running on smart TVs and set-top boxes. * [[Android TV]] – version of Android made for TVs * [[Glass OS]] – operating system for [[Google Glass]] * [[Google Fuchsia]] - unreleased OS predicted to be for laptops and smartphones
== Desktop applications == <!-- Include supported platforms at the end of an annotation. --> * [[AdWords Editor]] – desktop application to manage a [[Google AdWords]] account; lets users make changes to their account and advertising campaigns before synchronizing with the online service. * [[Google Chrome]] – web browser * [[Google Earth]] – virtual 3D globe that uses satellite imagery, aerial photography, [[Geographic information system|GIS]] from Google's repository. * [[Google IME|Google Input Tools]] – [[Input method editor]] that allows users to enter text in one of the supported languages using a Roman keyboard.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.google.com/inputtools/windows/|title = Google Input Tools on Windows [Discontinued] |date = |accessdate=January 22, 2016|website = Google Input Tools|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> * [[Google Japanese Input]] – Japanese [[input method editor]]. * [[Google Pinyin]] – [[input method editor]] that is used to convert [[Pinyin]] characters, which can be entered on Western-style keyboards, to Chinese characters. * [[Google Toolbar]] – web browser toolbar with features such as a Google Search box, pop-up blocker and ability for website owners to create buttons. * [[Android Studio]] – [[integrated development environment]] for Android * [[Google Web Designer]] – [[WYSIWYG]] editor for making rich [[HTML5]] pages and ads intended to run on multiple devices * [[Google Drive#Client|Google Drive]] – client software to synchronize files between the user's computer and Google Drive storage. * [[Google Photos|Google Photos Backup]] – back up photos and videos to Google Photos service * [[Nik Collection]] - Image editing plugins for [[Adobe Photoshop version history|Adobe Photoshop]] * [[Tilt Brush]] - painting game for the [[HTC Vive|Vive]] and [[Oculus Rift]] * [[Backup and Sync]] - client application for Google Drive and Google Photos
== Mobile applications{{anchor|Mobile}}{{anchor|Google Mobile}} == === Mobile web applications === These products can be accessed through a [[Web browser|browser]] on a mobile device. * Blogger Mobile – U.S. and Canadian networks only. Allows updating [[Blogger (service)|Blogger]] from mobile devices. * [[Google Calendar]] – display Google Calendar events on a mobile device; users can quickly add events to personal calendars. * [[Google Drive|Drive]] – view documents on a mobile device * [[Gmail]] – access a Gmail account from a mobile device using a mobile [[web browser]]. Google provides a specific mobile application to access Gmail messages. * [[Google Keep]] – create, access and organize notes, lists and photos * [[Google Maps]] – find local businesses, view maps and get driving directions * [[Google Maps Navigation|Maps Navigation]] – navigation application for GPS-enabled mobile devices with 3D views, voice guided [[turn-by-turn navigation]] and automatic rerouting * Mobilizer – optimize web pages for mobile web browsers * [[Google News]] – access Google News * [[Google Offers]] – with [[Google Wallet]], combine coupons, discounts and payments for people buying things through their phone.<ref name="news.cnet.com">Erica Ogg, CNET. "[http://news.cnet.com/8301-31021_3-20066478-260.html?part=rss&subj=news&tag=2547-1_3-0-20 Google unveils mobile payments, coupon service]." May 26, 2011. Retrieved May 26, 2011.</ref> * [[Google+]] – social network, competing with [[Facebook]] * [[Google Product Search]] – easily search for information about a product * [[Google Photos]] – unlimited video and photo storage for personal use * [[Google Search]] – search webpages, images, videos and more * [[Google Search for Android]] – Google Search app for Android * [[Google Tez]] – Android payment app that uses the [[Unified Payments Interface]] for Indian consumers * [[Google Pay]] – smartphone wallet using [[Near-field communication|near field communication]]<ref name="news.cnet.com" /> * [[Google Pay Send]] – peer-to-peer payments service under [[Google Pay]] *[[Google Translate]] – online language translation service * [[YouTube]] – [[Video hosting service]] that publishes to a public web site available for both desktop and mobile *[[Quick, Draw!]] - online game based around a [[neural network]] guessing what a drawing represents, intended to teach people about machine learning
=== Mobile standalone applications ===
* [[Google Authenticator]] – [[Multi-factor authentication|MFA]] ([[Multi-factor authentication]]) *[[Google Play Books]] – buy and download books and keep them stored on remote servers, allows reading one book on a variety of devices.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101206/ap_on_hi_te/us_tec_google_books Google opens e-book store in challenge to Amazon] {{webarchive |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20101209162415/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101206/ap_on_hi_te/us_tec_google_books |date= December 9, 2010 }}</ref> * [[Gmail]] – email app * [[Google Catalogs|Catalogs]] – shopping application for [[Tablet computer|tablet computers]] * [[Google Drive|Drive]] – access files and documents stored on Google Drive. * Files Go – Android storage cleanup, file-browsing and offline file-transfer * [[Google Keep]] – note-taking and web surfing * [[Google Goggles]] – search based on pictures taken with a device's built-in camera; taking pictures of things (examples: famous landmarks, product bar-codes) causes searches for information on them.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.google.com/mobile/goggles/ |title= Google Goggles |publisher= Google |accessdate= March 16, 2013}}</ref> * [[Project Tango|Tango]] - [[augmented reality]], indoor navigation, [[Three-dimensional space (mathematics)|3D]] mapping, physical space measurement and environmental recognition. It also allows developers to create applications using its APIs. * [[Google Maps (mobile application)|Google Maps]] – view maps * [[Google Play Music]] {{anchor|Music}}{{anchor|Google Music}} – online music [[store (disambiguation) | store]] <ref> [http://www.trillionclues.com/2018/06/google-new-podcast-app-android-apk.html Google Podcast will be an open platform environment for induals to create and manage podcasts: '[[Google Podcast]]' the platform will be free for all and also open to improving onideas] June, 2018</ref> <ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2011/feb/16/google-music-itunes-competitor-android Google will launch iTunes music store competitor with upgrade to Android: '[[Google Music]]' service will form part of new version of Android operating system designed specifically for tablet devices] February 16, 2011</ref> * [[Google Play Newsstand]] – news aggregator that combines the features of the discontinued apps Google Play Magazines and Google Currents * [[Google Podcasts]] – podcasts client app for Android * [[One Today]] – allows people to donate to nonprofits that are part of the Google for nonprofits program, . * Shopper – makes [[shopping]] easier and smarter.<!-- How? Be brief. --> * [[Sky Map]] – augmented-reality program displaying a star map that shifts perspective following the device's movement * [[Google Primer]] - teaches digital-marketing skills * [[Google Sync]] – synchronizes mobile phones with multiple Google calendars and contacts * [[Google Talk]] – [[VoIP]] and texting * [[Google Hangouts|Hangouts]] – instant-messaging and video-chat platform * Translate – translate conversations * Google Voice * Yinyue (''Music'') ([[Google China]]) – {{anchor|Yinyue}}{{anchor|Google Yinyue}} site linking to a large archive of Chinese pop-music (principally [[Cantopop]] and [[Mandopop]]), including audio streaming over Google's own player, legal lyric downloads, and in most cases legal MP3 downloads. The archive is provided by Top100.cn (i.e., this service does not search the whole Internet) and is available in [[mainland China]] only. * [[YouTube]] * YouTube Remote – control YouTube video that plays on a TV *[[Google Now]] – personal assistant operated through voice commands * [[Google+]] (G+) – social network * [[Waze]] – input and view live traffic and alerts. * Who's Down – indicate social availability to one's friends.<ref>whosdown.com</ref> * Gboard (Google Keyboard for iOS and Android) - touchscreen keyboard that features glide typing, GIF search, emoji search and Google search<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.theverge.com/2016/3/22/11287220/google-keyboard-iOS-search|title= Google is making a keyboard for the iPhone|date= March 22, 2016|publisher= |accessdate= March 26, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.theverge.com/2016/5/12/11662616/google-gboard-keyboard-iphone-ios|title= Google releases keyboard for the iPhone with built-in search features|last= Seifert|first= Dan|date= May 12, 2016|website= The Verge|access-date= November 24, 2016}}</ref>
== Hardware == * Google Search Appliance – [[search appliance]] designed for indexing corporate data * [[Google driverless car]] – autonomous vehicle * [[Nexus One]] – 3.7" phone running Android 2.3 "Gingerbread" * [[Nexus S]] – 4" phone running Android 4.1 "Jelly Bean" * [[Galaxy Nexus]] – 4.7" phone running Android 4.3 "Jelly Bean" * [[Nexus Q]] – media streaming entertainment device in the Google Nexus product family * [[Nexus 7 (2012)]] – 7" tablet running Android 5.1 "Lollipop" * [[Nexus 7 (2013)]] – 7" tablet running Android 6.0 "Marshmallow" * [[Nexus 4]] – 4.7" phone running Android 5.1 "Lollipop" * [[Nexus 5]] – 4.95" phone running [[Android (operating system)|Android]] 6.0 "Marshmallow" * [[Nexus 6]] – 5.96" phone running Android 7.1.1 "Nougat"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/nexus/6/|title=Nexus 6P|work=google.com}}</ref> * [[Nexus 9]] – 9" tablet running Android 7.1 "Nougat" * [[Nexus 10]] – 10" tablet running Android 5.1 "Lollipop" * [[Nexus 5X]] – 5" phone running Android 8.1 "Oreo" * [[Nexus 6P]] – 5.7" phone running Android 8.1 "Oreo"<ref>{{cite web | url = https://store.google.com/product/nexus_6p | title = Nexus 6P - Solid Metal Frame - Huawei - Nexus - Android Phones - Google Store | website = store.google.com | access-date = February 25, 2016 }}</ref> * [[Nexus Player]] – streaming media player running Android 8.0 "Oreo" * [[Pixel C]] – 10.2" convertible tablet running Android 8.1 "Oreo" * [[Chromebook]] – laptop computer running Chrome OS * [[Chromebook Pixel]] – laptop computer running Chrome OS * [[Pixelbook]] — laptop running Chrome OS * [[Chromebox]] – desktop computer running Chrome OS * [[Chromecast]] – media streaming adapter * [[Chromecast Ultra]] – [[4K resolution|4K]]-capable media streaming adapter * [[Chromecast Audio]] – audio streaming adapter * [[Google Glass]] – wearable computer with an optical head-mounted display and camera that allows the wearer to interact with various applications and the Internet via natural language voice commands * [[Google Contact Lens]] – [[contact lens]] capable of monitoring the user's glucose level in tears. It is not yet released. * [[Google OnHub]] – [[Router (computing)|router]] line * [[Google Daydream View]] – [[virtual reality]] headset for smartphones * [[Google Home]] – [[smart speaker]] line * [[Google Wifi]] – router * [[Pixel (smartphone)|Pixel]] – 5" smartphone running [[Android (operating system)|Android]] 9 "Pie" * [[Pixel (smartphone)|Pixel XL]] – 5.5" smartphone running Android 9 "Pie" * [[Pixel 2]] – 5" smartphone running Android 9 "Pie" * [[Pixel 2|Pixel 2 XL]] – 6" smartphone running Android 9 "Pie" * [[Pixel 3]] – 5" smartphone running Android 9 "Pie" * [[Pixel 3|Pixel 3 XL]] – 6" smartphone running Android 9 "Pie" * [[Nest Labs]] devices * [[Android One|Android One smartphones]] – smartphones from multiple manufacturers * [[Jamboard]] - 55" interactive whiteboard
== Services == * [[Google Cloud Platform]] – modular cloud-based services for software development * [[Google Crisis Response]] – public project that covers disasters, turmoils and other emergencies and alerts * [[Google Fi]] – cell phone plan aimed at simple plans and pricing * [[Google Fiber]] – experimental broadband internet network infrastructure using fiberoptic communication in Kansas City, [[Provo, Utah|Provo]] and [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] * [[Google Get Your Business Online]] – increase the web presence of small businesses and cities. Advice on [[search engine optimization]] and maintaining business owners update their business profile.<ref>Clancy, Heather (March 6, 2012). [http://www.zdnet.com/article/google-lures-small-businesses-with-free-web-site-offer "Google lures small businesses with free Web site offer"]. [[ZDnet]]</ref> * [[Google Station]] – public [[Wi-Fi]] that can be monetized through ads * [[Google Public DNS]] – publicly accessible [[domain Name System|DNS]] server * [[Google Ideas]] – cross-sector, interdisciplinary "think tank" or "think/do tank" based in New York City, dedicated to understanding global challenges and applying technological solutions. * [[Google Person Finder]] – open-source tool that helps people reconnect with others in the aftermath of a disaster * [[Accelerated Mobile Pages|Google Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP)]] – open-source project and service to accelerate content on mobile devices.<ref>{{cite web|title = Google has a new plan to speed up the mobile web|url = https://www.theverge.com/2015/10/7/9467149/google-accelerated-mobile-pages-caching-preview|website = The Verge|date=October 7, 2015|accessdate = October 11, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ampproject.org/|title=Accelerated Mobile Pages Project|work=ampproject.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/google-wants-news-articles-to-load-on-your-phone-in-an-instant/#ftag=CAD590a51e|title=Google wants news articles to load on your phone in an instant|date=October 7, 2015|publisher=CBS Interactive|work=CNET}}</ref> AMP provides a JavaScript library for developers and restricts the use of third-party JS.<ref>{{cite web|title = Implement Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) and Optimize the Website to Next Level|url = http://www.mustips.com/implement-accelerated-mobile-pages-amp/|website = MUS Tips|date=March 5, 2016|accessdate = April 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.resultfirst.com/knowledgecenter/know-about-google-amp/ |title=Things You Need To Know About Google AMP (Accelerated Mobile Pages) |website=ResultFirst|date= March 29, 2016 |author=Ruchi Pardal |accessdate= December 27, 2016}}</ref> * [[Firebase|Google Firebase]] – real time database that provides an [[API]] that allows developers to store and sync data across multiple clients * [[Google Cast]] – display entertainment and apps from a phone, tablet or laptop right on a TV or speakers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mothod.com/trends/74-currently-active-subdomains-google-com/|title=74 currently active subdomains of Google.com - MOTHOD|date=September 27, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=March 26, 2017}}</ref>
== Discontinued products and services == Google has retired many offerings, either because of obsolescence, integration into other Google products, or lack of interest.<ref>{{cite web| title= The Google Graveyard | first1=Heather| last1= Brady| first2= Chris| last2= Kirk | date=March 15, 2013|url= http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/map_of_the_week/2013/03/google_reader_joins_graveyard_of_dead_google_products.html | publisher= [[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] | accessdate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> Google's discontinued offerings are colloquially referred to as Google Graveyard.<ref>{{cite web| title= Google Graveyard Does Exist | first1=Logan| last1= Booker| date=March 17, 2013|url= https://www.gizmodo.com.au/2013/03/google-graveyard-does-exist-you-can-even-place-flowers-on-your-deceased-favourites/ | publisher= [[Gizmodo]] | accessdate=May 17, 2018}}</ref>
=== 2006 === * [[Google Answers]] – online knowledge market that allowed users to post bounties for well-researched answers to their queries. Discontinued on November 28; still accessible (read-only). * Google Deskbar – desktop bar with a built-in mini browser. Replaced by a similar feature in [[Google Desktop]]. Discontinued May 8. * [[Writely]] – web-based [[word processor]]. On October 10, Writely was merged into Google Docs & Spreadsheets.
=== 2007 === * [[AdWords#Google Click-to-Call|Google Click-to-Call]] – allowed a user to speak directly over the phone without charge to businesses found on Google search results pages. * Related Links – links to information related to a website's content. Discontinued on April 30. * Public Service Search – non-commercial organization service, which included Google Site Search, traffic reports and unlimited search queries. Discontinued on February, replaced by [[Google Custom Search]]. * Google Video Marketplace – discontinued in August<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=https://techcrunch.com/2007/08/10/google-closes-video-marketplace-users-out-of-luck/ |title=Google Closes Video Marketplace; Users Out Of Luck |publisher=TechCrunch |date=August 10, 2007 |accessdate=June 14, 2013}}</ref>
=== 2008 === * [[Google Browser Sync]] ([[Firefox|Mozilla Firefox]]) – allowed Firefox users to synchronize settings across multiple computers. Discontinued in June. * [[Google Lively]] – 3D animated chat. Discontinued December 31.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2008/11/lively-no-more.html |title=Lively no more |work=Google Blog |date=November 19, 2008}}</ref> * [[Picasa#Hello|Hello]] – send images across the Internet and publish them to blogs. Discontinued on May 15.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://readwrite.com/2008/05/08/google_closes_hello/|title=Google Says Goodbye to Hello|first1=Posted on May|last1=8|first2=2008 in|last2=Web|date=May 8, 2008|publisher=|accessdate=March 26, 2017}}</ref> * SearchMash – search engine to "test innovative user interfaces". Discontinued on November 24.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/11/24/why-did-google-discontinue-searchmash/|title=Why Did Google Discontinue SearchMash?|first=Robin|last=Wauters|publisher=|accessdate=March 26, 2017}}</ref> * Send to Phone – send links and other information from [[Firefox]] to their phone by [[text messaging|text message]]. Discontinued on August 28, replaced by Google Chrome to Phone.<ref name=":0" /> * [[Google Web Accelerator|Web Accelerator]] – increased load speed of web pages. No longer available for, or supported by, Google as of January 20.
=== 2009 === * Audio Ads – radio advertising program for US businesses. Discontinued on February 12. * Catalogs – search engine for over 6,600 print catalogs, acquired through [[optical character recognition]]. Discontinued in January. * [[Dodgeball (service)|Dodgeball]] – [[social networking service]]. Users could text their location to the service, which would then notify them of nearby people or events of interest. Replaced by [[Google Latitude]]. * [[Google Mashup Editor]] – web mashup creation with publishing, syntax highlighting, debugging. Discontinued in July; migrated to Google App Engine. * [[Google Ride Finder]] – taxi and shuttle search service, using real time position of vehicles in 14 U.S. cities. Used the [[Google Maps]] interface and cooperated with any car service that wished to participate. Discontinued in October. * Shared Stuff – web page sharing system, incorporating a [[bookmarklet]] to share pages, and a page to view the most popular shared items. Pages could be shared through third party applications such as Delicious or [[Facebook]]. Discontinued on March 30. * [[Google Page Creator]] – webpage publishing program that could be used to create pages and to host them on Google servers. Discontinued, with all existing content transferred to [[Google Sites]].
=== 2010 === * Marratech e-Meeting – [[web conferencing]] software, used internally by Google's employees. Discontinued on February 19. * [[Google SearchWiki]] – annotate and re-order search results. Discontinued March 3, replaced by Google Stars. * [[GOOG-411]] (also known as Voice Local Search) – [[directory assistance]] service. Discontinued on November 12. * [[Google Base]] – submission database that enabled content owners to submit content, have it hosted and made searchable. Information was organized using attributes. Discontinued on December 17, replaced with Google Shopping APIs.
=== 2011 === * [[Google Labs]] – test and demonstrate new Google products * [[Google Buzz]] – social networking service integrated with [[Gmail]] allowing users to share content immediately and make conversations. Discontinued in December.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pepitone |first=Julianne |url=http://money.cnn.com/2011/10/14/technology/google_buzz_shut_down/index.htm |title=Buzz will be replaced by Google+ |publisher=CNN Money |date=October 14, 2011 |accessdate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> * [[Google PowerMeter]] – view building energy consumption. Discontinued on September 16. * [[Real Estate]] – place real estate listings in Google Maps. Discontinued February 10.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://google-latlong.blogspot.com/2011/01/retiring-real-estate-on-google-maps.html|title=Retiring Real Estate on Google Maps|publisher=Google|date=January 26, 2011}}</ref> * [[Google Directory]] – collection of links arranged into hierarchical subcategories. The links and their categorization were from the [[Open Directory Project]], sorted using [[PageRank]]. Discontinued on July 20. * [[Google Blog Search]] – [[weblog]] search engine. Discontinued in July. * [[Google Squared|Squared]] – creates tables of information about a subject from [[unstructured data]]. Discontinued September. * Google Sets – generates a list of items when users enter a few examples. For example, entering "Green, Purple, Red" emits the list "Green, Purple, Red, Blue, Black, White, Yellow, Orange, Brown". Discontinued mid-year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://searchenginewatch.com/article/2111106/Rock-the-Vote-A-Petition-to-Bring-Back-Google-Sets |title=Rock the Vote: A Petition to Bring Back Google Sets |publisher=Search Engine Watch |accessdate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> * [[Google Pack]] – application suite. Discontinued on September 2. * [[Google Fast Flip]] – online news aggregator. Discontinued September 6. * [[Google Desktop|Desktop]] – [[Desktop environment|desktop]] search application that indexed emails, documents, music, photos, chats, Web history and other files. Discontinued on September 14. * [[Aardvark (search engine)|Aardvark]] – social search utility that allowed people to ask and answer questions within their social networks. It used people's claimed expertise to match 'askers' with good 'answerers'. Discontinued on September 30. * [[Google Sidewiki]] – browser sidebar and service that allowed contributing and reading helpful information alongside any web page. Discontinued in December. * Directory{{anchor|Directory}} – navigation directory, specifically for Chinese users.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://searchenginewatch.com/article/2096661/Google-Directory-Has-Been-Shut-Down|title=Google Directory Has Been Shut Down|author=Rob D. Young|work=Search Engine Watch}}</ref> * [[Gears (software)|Gears]] – web browser features, enabling some new web applications. * [[Google Places|Hotpot]] – local recommendation engine that allowed people to rate restaurants, hotels etc. and share them with friends. Moved to Google Places service in April 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mashable.com/2011/04/08/google-hotpot-goes-cold/#6.bg_Ay.Miq1|title=Google Goes Cold on Hotpot, Shutters the Standalone App|last=Grove|first=Jennifer Van|work=Mashable|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en}}</ref>
=== 2012 === * [[Google Notebook]] – online note-taking and web-clipping application.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://googlenotebookblog.blogspot.com/2009/01/stopping-development-on-google-notebook.html |title=Stopping development on Google notebook |last=Krishnan |first=Raj |work=Google Notebook Blog |date=January 14, 2009}}</ref> Discontinued in July. * [[Google Apps]] Standard Edition – Discontinued on December 6.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lee |first=Michael |url=http://www.zdnet.com/google-kills-off-free-google-apps-offering-7000008467/ |title=Google kills off free Google Apps offering |publisher=ZDNet |date=December 7, 2012 |accessdate=March 16, 2013}}</ref> * [[Google Code Search]] – software search engine. Discontinued on January 15.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2011/10/fall-sweep.html |title=A fall sweep |author=Bradley Horowitz |work=Google Blog |date=October 14, 2011}}</ref> * [[Google Health]] – store, manage, and share personal health information in one place. Development ceased June 24, 2011; accessible until January 1, 2012; data available for download until January 1, 2013. * [[Google Website Optimizer]] – testing and optimization tool. Discontinued on August 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://websiteoptimizer.blogspot.com/2012/08/saying-goodbye-to-google-website.html|title=Official Google Website Optimizer Blog: Saying goodbye to the Google Website Optimizer Blog|work=websiteoptimizer.blogspot.com}}</ref> * TV Ads – Method to place advertising on TV networks. Discontinued on August 30,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://google-tvads.blogspot.com/2012/08/an-update-on-google-tv-ads.html|title=An update on Google TV Ads|last=Mehrotra|first=Shishir}}</ref> with all remaining active campaigns ending December 16.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://support.google.com/tvads/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=176110&ctx=cb&src=cb&cbid=ytzwv1tdmlad|title=TV Ads Help|work=Google Support}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=Darkmorpher |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * [[Google Friend Connect]] – add social features to websites. Discontinued on March 1, replaced by [[Google+]]'s pages and off-site Page badges.<ref name="more spring cleaning">{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2011/11/more-spring-cleaning-out-of-season.html |title=More spring cleaning out of season |author=Urs Hölzle |work=Google Blog |date=November 22, 2011}}</ref> * [[Google Insights for Search]] – insights into Google search term usage. Discontinued September 27, merged in Google Trends. * [[Knol]] – write authoritative articles related to various topics. Discontinued October 1.<ref name="more spring cleaning" /> * [[Google Wave]] – online communication and [[collaborative real-time editor]] tool. Support ended on April 30, 2012.<ref name="more spring cleaning" /> * [[Picnik]] – online photo editor. Discontinued on April 19,<ref name="Picnik is closing">{{cite web|title=Official Announcement: Picnik is closing |url=http://blog.picnik.com/2012/01/official-announcement-picnik-is-closing/ |accessdate=January 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120123011119/http://blog.picnik.com/2012/01/official-announcement-picnik-is-closing/ |archivedate=January 23, 2012 |df= }}</ref> moved to Google+ photo manager. * [[Jaiku]] – [[social networking]], [[microblogging]] and [[lifestreaming]] service comparable to [[Twitter]]. * [[Nexus Q]] – [[digital media player]]. Discontinued in November. * [[Slide.com]] – Discontinued on March 6.<ref>{{cite web|title=Top 10 google product|url=http://www.shoutingblogger.com/2015/01/Top-10-Popular-Google-Products.html|website=Shoutingblogger.com|accessdate=January 24, 2015}}</ref> * [[Google Mini]] – reduced capacity, lower-cost version of the Google Search Appliance. Discontinued on July 31.<ref name="summer cleaning">{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2012/07/spring-cleaning-in-summer.html |title=Spring cleaning in summer |author=Matt Eichner |work=Google Blog |date=July 3, 2012}}</ref> * [[Picasa Web Albums Uploader]] – upload images to the "[[Picasa]] Web Albums" service. It consisted of an [[iPhoto]] plug-in and a stand-alone application.<ref>{{cite web|title=Picasa Web Albums Uploader for Mac is no longer available for download|url=https://productforums.google.com/forum/#!topic/picasa/kNQoLm-8E6Q|website=Google Groups|accessdate=January 22, 2016}}</ref> * [[Google Chart API]] - interactive Web-based chart image generator, deprecated in 2012 with service commitment to 2015 and still serving as of 2017. Google promotes JavaScript-based [[Google Charts]] as a replacement, which is not backwards-compatible with the Google Chart API's HTTP methods. * Listen – subscribe to and stream podcasts and Web audio. Discontinued in August.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://googleblog.blogspot.com/2012/08/giving-you-better-google.html|title=Giving you a better Google|publisher=Google|accessdate=February 17, 2017}}</ref> * [[BumpTop]] – physics-based desktop application. Discontinued in August.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/bumptop/BumpTop|title=bumptop/BumpTop|website=GitHub|language=en|access-date=March 26, 2017}}</ref> * [[OpenRefine|Google Refine]] – data cleansing and processing. It was spun off from Google on October 2, becoming open source; it is now OpenRefine.
=== 2013 === * [[Google Cloud Connect]] – [[Microsoft Office]] [[Plug-in (computing)|plugin]] for automatically backing up Office documents upon saving onto Google Docs. Discontinued on April 30, in favor of Google Drive.<ref name="spring two">{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2013/03/a-second-spring-of-cleaning.html |title=A second spring of cleaning |author=Urs Hölzle |work=Google Blog |date=March 13, 2013}}</ref> * [[Google Building Maker]] – web-based building and editing tool to create 3D buildings for Google Earth. Discontinued on June 4. * Google Calendar Sync – sync Microsoft Outlook email and calendar with Gmail and Google Calendar. Synchronization for existing installations stopped on August 1, 2014. Replaced with Google Sync, which does not synchronize Outlook calendars, but can sync email using IMAP or POP3. Also, Google Apps for Business, Education, and Government customers can use Google Apps Sync for Microsoft Outlook <ref>{{cite web|url=https://support.google.com/calendar/answer/6054804|title=Calendar Help|work=google.com}}</ref> * [[Meebo]] – A social networking website discontinued on June 6 * [[Google Reader]] – web-based [[news aggregator]], capable of reading [[Atom (standard)|Atom]] and [[RSS (file format)|RSS]] feeds. Discontinued on July 1.<ref name="spring two" /> * [[Google Latitude]] – mobile geolocation tool that lets friends know where users are. Discontinued on August 9, with some functionality moved to Google+.<ref>[https://support.google.com/gmm/answer/3001634?p=maps_android_latitude&rd=1 Latitude retired – Maps for mobile Help]. Support.google.com (July 10, 2013). Retrieved on 2013-07-21.</ref> * [[Google Talk]] – instant messaging service that provided both text and voice communication. Replaced May 15, by [[Google Hangouts]]. * SMS – [[mobile phone]] [[short message service]]. Discontinued on May 10.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lunden |first=Ingrid |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/05/12/google-kills-sms-search/ |title=Google Quietly Kills SMS Search, Closing One Way Of Connecting With Mobile Users Who Don’t Have Data Plans |publisher=AOL Inc |date=May 12, 2013 |accessdate=June 30, 2013}}</ref> * [[iGoogle]] – customisable homepage, which can contain [[web feed]]s and Google Gadgets. Discontinued on November 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://support.google.com/websearch/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=2664197|title=What happened to iGoogle?|work=google.com}}</ref> * [[Google Checkout]] – online payment processing service, aimed at simplifying the process of paying for online purchases. Discontinued on November 20, merged into Google Wallet. * My Maps, GIS tools for Google Maps
=== 2014 === * [[Google Schemer]] – social search to find local activities. Discontinued on February 7. * [[Google Notifier]] – alerted users to new messages in their Gmail account. Discontinued on January 31.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/1/16/5316748/google-quietly-kills-off-its-notifier-service-for-mail-and-calendar|title=Google quietly kills off its Notifier service for mail and calendar events|author=Josh Lowensohn|publisher=Vox Media|work=The Verge}}</ref> * YouTube My Speed. Discontinued in January, replaced by Google Video Quality Report. * [[Orkut]] – social networking website. Discontinued on September 30. * [[QuickOffice]] – productivity suite for mobile devices. Discontinued in June, merged into Google Drive. * Google's "discussion search" option. Discontinued in July.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.seroundtable.com/google-discussion-search-dead-18854.html|title=Google Completely Disables Discussion Search Feature|work=seroundtable.com}}</ref> * [[Google Questions and Answers]] – community-driven knowledge market website. Discontinued on December 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://googlerussiablog.blogspot.com/2007/06/google.html |title="Вопросы и ответы" Google |author=Грег Коладонато, менеджер по продуктам (Маунтин Вью, США) |work=Официальный блог – Google Россия |date=June 28, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Chitu|first1=Alex|title=Google Discontinues Q&A Services|url=http://googlesystem.blogspot.com/2014/07/google-discontinues-q-services.html|website=Google Discontinues Q&A Services|accessdate=March 14, 2017|date=July 1, 2014}}</ref>
=== 2015 === * [[Google Moderator]] – rank user-submitted questions, suggestions and ideas via crowdsourcing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1sPmkuVqoHKue7SlL3tSLrDsyufB8owMeR8AHx4LG8FA/pub|title=Moderator shutdown announcement|work=google.com}}</ref> Discontinued on June 30. * Wildfire by Google – social media marketing software<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/google-ends-wildfire-2014-3|title=Google Ends Wildfire – Business Insider|date=March 14, 2014|work=Business Insider}}</ref> * [[BebaPay]] – prepaid ticket payment system. Discontinued on March 15.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/Google-quits-cashless-fare-business/-/539550/2625662/-/lniipoz/-/index.html|title = Google quits cashless fare business after BebaPay exit|date = February 15, 2015|access-date = February 11, 2016|website = [[Business Daily Africa]]|publisher = [[Nation Media Group]]|last = Okutta|first = Mark}}</ref> * [[Google Helpouts]] – Hangout-based live video chat with experts. Discontinued on April 20.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://helpouts.google.com/|title = Google Hangouts' official website|date = |accessdate=February 13, 2015|website = Helpouts by Google|publisher = Google|last = |first = }}</ref> * Google Earth Enterprise – Google Earth for enterprise use. Discontinued on March 20. * Google Earth Plugin – customize Google Earth. Discontinued on December 15.
===2016=== * [[Google Code]] – Open source code hosting. Discontinued on January 25.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://google-opensource.blogspot.com/2015/03/farewell-to-google-code.html |title=Bidding farewell to Google Code |work=Google Open Source Blog |date=March 12, 2015}}</ref> * [[Picasa]] – photo organization and editing application. Replaced by Google Photos.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sabharwal|first1=Anil |title=Moving on From Picasa|url=http://googlephotos.blogspot.com/2016/02/moving-on-from-picasa.html|website=|publisher=|accessdate=February 12, 2016}}</ref> * Google Compare – comparison-shopping site for auto insurance, credit cards and mortgages<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-google-comparison-idUSKCN0VW06Q|title=Google is shuttering Google Compare: WSJ|date=February 23, 2017|publisher=|accessdate=March 26, 2017|via=Reuters}}</ref> * Google Showtimes – move showtime search engine. Discontinued on November 1.<ref>{{cite web|title=Google quietly shutters standalone Google Showtimes movie site |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/11/07/google-quietly-shutters-standalone-google-showtimes-movie-site/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |date=November 7, 2016 |accessdate=January 4, 2017 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6nGTc4eYW?url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/11/07/google-quietly-shutters-standalone-google-showtimes-movie-site/ |archivedate=January 4, 2017 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> * [[MyTracks]] – GPS logging<ref>{{cite web|author=Thursday, Jan 28, 2016 at 8:01 am EST |url=http://www.androidcentral.com/google-will-shut-down-its-fitness-tracking-app-my-tracks-april-30 |title=Google will shut down My Tracks on April 30 |publisher=Android Central |date=2016-01-28 |accessdate=2017-11-07}}</ref> * [[Project Ara]] – an "initiative to build a phone with interchangeable modules for various components like cameras and batteries"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/circuitbreaker/2016/9/1/12762236/google-project-ara-suspended-modular-phone-report|title=Google reportedly cancels Project Ara modular smartphone plans|publisher=|accessdate=March 26, 2017}}</ref> was suspended to "streamline the company's seemingly disorganized product lineup".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/9/2/12775922/google-project-ara-modular-phone-suspended-confirm|title=Google confirms the end of its modular Project Ara smartphone|date=September 2, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=March 26, 2017}}</ref> on September 2. * [[Panoramio]] – [[geotagging|geolocation-oriented]] [[photo sharing]] website. Discontinued on November 4.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.panoramio.com/maps-faq|title=Panoramio - Help - Copy Photos to Google Maps|publisher=|accessdate=March 26, 2017}}</ref> Google's Local Guides program as well as photo upload tools in Google Maps rendered Panoramio redundant. * Google Feed API – download public Atom or RSS feeds using JavaScript. Deactivated on December 15.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://developers.google.com/feed/|title=Google Feed API - Google Developers|publisher=|accessdate=March 26, 2017}}</ref> * [https://mapsengine.google.com/about/index.html Google Maps Engine] – develop geospatial applications. Discontinued February 1. * [[Google Swiffy]] – convert [[Adobe Flash]] files ([[SWF]]) into [[HTML5]]. Discontinued July 1. * [[Google Nexus]] - Smartphone lineup - replaced by Google Pixel on October 4
===2017=== * Free Search – embed site/web search into a user's website. Replaced by [[Google Custom Search]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2017/02/21/google-site-search-discontinued/|title=Google Plans To Discontinue Yet Another Product|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en}}</ref> * Google Hands Free - retail checkout without using your phone or watch. Pilot started in the Bay area March 2016, but discontinued on February 8.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.slashgear.com/google-shutting-down-hands-free-next-week-02473609/|title=Google Shutting Down Hands Free Next Week}}</ref> * [[Google Spaces]] – group discussions and messaging. Discontinued on April 17.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://support.google.com/spaces/answer/7326586|title=Google Spaces will be shut down on April 17th, 2017 - Spaces Help|publisher=|accessdate=March 26, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170226213415/https://support.google.com/spaces/answer/7326586|archivedate=February 26, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[Google Map Maker]] – map editor with browser interface. Discontinued on April 1, replaced by Google Maps and Google Local Guides. * [[Trendalyzer]] – data trend viewing platform. Discontinued in September.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://gsuiteupdates.googleblog.com/2017/06/charts-in-sheets-updates_1.html|title=G Suite Updates: Visualize data instantly with machine learning in Google Sheets}}</ref>
===2018=== * [[Google Search#Encrypted search|Encrypted Search]] – anonymous internet searching. Discontinued on April 30. All Google products and all modern browsers automatically use HTTPS connections.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/7631341?hl=en|title= Encrypted.google.com is going away|website=Google Support|access-date=May 15, 2018}}</ref> In May 2010 Google rolled out SSL-encrypted web search.<ref>[https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/173733?hl=en SSL Search – Search Help]. Support.google.com. Retrieved on November 29, 2013.</ref> * [[Google Goggles|Goggles]] – Discontinued on August 15. Last app update directs users to [[Google Lens]] or [[Google Photos]].
=== Other === {{missing information|section|the discontinuation date of each product in this section|date=October 2013}} * Blogger Web Comments ([[Firefox]] only) – displays related comments from other [[Blogger (service)|Blogger]] users. * City Tours – overlay to Maps that shows interesting tours within a city * Dashboard Widgets for Mac ([[Mac OS X Dashboard]] Widgets) – suite of mini-applications including [[Gmail]], [[Blogger (service)|Blogger]] and Search History. * Joga Bonito – [[soccer]] community site. * Local – Local listings service, merged with Google Maps. * MK-14 – 4U rack mounted server for Google Radio Automation system. Google sold its Google Radio Automation business to WideOrbit Inc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wideorbit.com/wideorbit-products/wo-automation-for-radio|title=Radio Station Automation Software}}</ref> * [[Google Trends#Google Music Trends|Google Music Trends]] – music ranking of songs played with iTunes, Winamp, Windows Media Player and Yahoo Music. Trends were generated by [[Google Talk]]'s "share your music status" feature. * [[Personalized Search]] – search results personalization, merged with Google Accounts and Web History. * Photos Screensaver – slideshow [[screensaver]] as part of Google Pack, which displays images sourced from a [[hard disk]], or through [[RSS]] and [[Atom (standard)|Atom]] Web feeds. * Rebang (Google China) – search trend site, similar to Google Zeitgeist. {{As of|2010}}, part of Google Labs.<ref>[https://www.google.com.hk/intl/zh-CN_cn/rebang/error.html About Google Rebang Service] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925191229/https://www.google.com.hk/intl/zh-CN_cn/rebang/error.html |date=September 25, 2010 }}</ref><ref>[https://www.google.com.hk/ggblog/googlechinablog/2010/07/google_20.html 有关Google中国产品的更新情况："在中国，热榜和生活这两个产品没有受到中国用户的广泛欢迎，因此，我们决定关闭这两个产品。"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100919112018/https://www.google.com.hk/ggblog/googlechinablog/2010/07/google_20.html |date=September 19, 2010 }}</ref> * Spreadsheets – spreadsheet management application, before it was integrated with Writely to form Google Docs & Spreadsheets. * University Search – search engine listing for university websites. * U.S. Government Search – search engine and personalized homepage that exclusively draws from sites with a [[.gov]] [[TLD]]. Discontinued June 2006. * [[Google Video#Google Video Player|Video Player]] – view videos from Google Video. * [[Voice Search]] – automated voice system for web search using the telephone. Became Google Voice Local Search and integrated on the Google Mobile web site. * Google X – redesigned Google search homepage. It appeared in Google Labs, but disappeared the following day for undisclosed reasons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com/2100-1032-5621247.html?tag=yt|title=Google's X files vanish|work=CNET}}</ref> * Accessible Search – search engine for the visually impaired. * [[Google Quick Search Box|Quick Search Box]] – search box, based on [[Quicksilver (software)|Quicksilver]], easing access to installed applications and online searches. * Visigami – image search application screen saver that searches files from [[Google Images]], [[Picasa]] and [[Flickr]]. * [[Google WiFi#Wireless access|Wireless access]] – [[VPN]] client for [[Google WiFi]] users, whose equipment does not support [[Wi-Fi Protected Access|WPA]] or [[802.1x]] protocols. * Google global market finder {{div col end}}
=== Scheduled to be discontinued === Applications that are no longer in development, and scheduled to be discontinued in the future: * [[Google Search Appliance]] – A rack mounted device used to index documents. End of hardware sales in 2017 and planned shutdown in 2018.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=So Long Google Search Appliance|url=http://fortune.com/2016/02/04/google-ends-search-appliance/|website=Fortune|accessdate=November 19, 2016}}</ref>- with final shutdown in 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://support.google.com/gsa/answer/7528111?hl=en|title=Google Search Appliance End of Life - Google Search Appliance Help|website=support.google.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref> * Google Portfolios – Personal financial securities tracker. Deprecated in November 2017. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://support.google.com/finance/answer/7534448 |title=Portfolios deprecation information - Finance Help |publisher=Support.google.com |date= |accessdate=2017-11-07}}</ref> * Goo.gl – a URL shortening service. Planned to be discontinued by March 2019.<ref name="engadget-goo-gl">{{Cite news|url=https://developers.googleblog.com/2018/03/transitioning-google-url-shortener.html|title=Transitioning Google URL Shortener to Firebase Dynamic Links|last=|first=|date=March 30, 2018|work=Google Developers Blog|access-date=July 9, 2018|language=en}}</ref> *[[Inbox by Gmail]] - an email application for Android, iOS, and web platform that organizes and automates to-do lists using email content. Planned to be discontinued by March 2019.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/9/12/17848500/google-inbox-shut-down-sunset-snooze-email-march-2019|title=Google’s Inbox app is shutting down in March 2019|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-09-16}}</ref> * [[Google+]] - The consumer edition of Google's social media platform will be closing in 2019.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.blog.google/technology/safety-security/project-strobe/|title=Project Strobe: Protecting your data, improving our third-party APIs, and sunsetting consumer Google+|work=Google Blog|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref> <!-- CHECK THE FOLLOWING LINKS. If a link is already included, delete it. If it isn't included in the outline yet, place it in the appropriate section. == Advertising == * [[Ad Manager]] – * [[AdMob]] – * [[Adscape]] – * [[AdSense]] – * [[Google Advertising Professional]] – * [[AdWords]] – * [[Google Analytics]] – * [[Google Checkout]] – * [[DoubleClick]] – * [[Google Offers]] – * [[Google Wallet]] –
== Communication == * [[Google Alerts]] – * [[Google Calendar]] – * [[Google Cloud Connect]] – * [[Google Contacts]] – * [[Google Dictionary]] – * [[Google Friend Connect]] – * [[Gmail]] – ** [[History of Gmail]] ** [[Gmail interface]] – * [[Google+]] – * [[Google Groups]] – * [[Google Talk]] – * [[Google Latitude]] – * [[Orkut]] – * [[Google Questions and Answers]] – * [[Google Reader]] – * [[Google Sync]] – * [[Google Translate]] – * [[Google Voice]] – * [[Google Wave]] –
== Software == * [[Google Chrome]] – ** [[Chrome Web Store]] – * [[Chrome OS]] – ** [[Chromebook]] – * [[Google Cloud Print]] – * [[Google Currents]] – * [[Google Earth]] – ** [[Google Sky]] – ** [[Google Moon]] – ** [[Google Mars]] – * [[Google Gadgets]] – * [[Google Goggles]] – * [[Google IME]] – ** [[Google Pinyin]] – ** [[Google Japanese Input]] – * [[Picasa]] – * [[Picnik]] – * [[SketchUp]] – * [[Google Talk]] – * [[Google Toolbar]] – * [[Google Pack#Google Updater|Google Updater]] – * [[Urchin (software)|Urchin]] –
== Google platforms == * [[Google platform]] – ** [[Google Account]] – ** [[Android (operating system)|Android]] – *** [[Google TV]] – *** [[Google Nexus]] – ** [[Google App Engine]] – ** [[Google Apps]] – ** [[BigTable]] – ** [[Google Body]] – ** [[Caja project]] – ** [[Google Custom Search]] – ** [[Dart (programming language)|Dart]] – ** [[Google Earth Engine]] – ** [[Go (programming language)|Go]] – ** [[Google File System]] – ** [[Google Music]] – ** [[Google Native Client]] – ** [[OpenSocial]] – ** [[Google Public DNS]] – ** [[Google Wallet]] – ** [[Google Wave Federation Protocol]] –
== Development tools == * [[Google AJAX APIs]] – * [[Google App Inventor]] – * [[AtGoogleTalks]] – * [[Google Closure Tools]] – * [[Google Gadgets API]] – * [[GData]] – * [[Googlebot]] – * [[Google Guice]] – * [[Google Web Server]] – * [[Keyhole Markup Language]] – * [[MapReduce]] – * [[SketchUp Ruby]] – * [[Sitemaps]] – * [[Google Summer of Code]] – * [[Google Web Toolkit]] – * [[Google Swiffy]] –
== Search == * [[Google Search]] – ** [[PageRank]] – ** [[Google Search Appliance]] – ** [[Google Audio Indexing]] – ** [[Google Books]] – *** [[Google Books Library Project]] – *** [[Google eBooks]] – ** [[Google Code Search]] – ** [[Google Dataset Search]] - ** [[Google Finance]] – ** [[Google Images]] – ** [[Google Maps]] – *** [[Google Street View]] – ** [[Google News]] – ** [[Google Patents]] – ** [[Google Product Search]] – ** [[Google Scholar]] – ** [[Google Groups]] – ** [[Google Videos]] – ** [[Google Search]] – *** [[Google Web History]] – *** [[Google Personalized Search]] – *** [[Google Real-Time Search]] – *** [[Instant Search]] – ** Analysis *** [[Google Insights for Search]] – *** [[Google Trends]] –
== Upcoming services == On April 4, 2012, Google announced plans to offer "[[augmented]]-[[reality]] [[glasses]]", which have been given the project title, "Project Glass". Google released a 2-minute and 30-second video of how the glasses might work. The glasses will be able to control music, get directions, take pictures, give voice commands and conduct video chats. While ''[[The New York Times]]'' originally reported that the glasses would be released sometime in 2012, Google stated that the glasses would likely not be released until a later year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allthingsd.com/20120404/google-unveils-project-glass-wearable-augmented-reality-glasses/?mod=atdtweet|title=Google Unveils Project Glass: Wearable Augmented-Reality Glasses|work=AllThingsD}}</ref>
== Other == * [[List of acquisitions by Google]] – * [[Google AI Challenge]] – * [[Google bomb]] – * [[Criticism of Google]] – * [[Google logo]] – * [[Google driverless car]] – * [[Google Fiber]] – * [[Google.org#Google Foundation]] – * [[Google China]] – * [[Google Grants]] – * [[Google.org]] – * [[Googleplex]] – * [[History of Google]] – * [[Google's hoaxes]] – * [[Google Search#"I'm Feeling Lucky"|I'm Feeling Lucky]] – * [[Google I/O|I/O]] – * [[Google logo]] – * [[Google Lunar X Prize]] – * [[Monopoly City Streets]] – * [[List of Google products]] – * [[Google Searchology]] – * [[Unity (cable system)|Unity]] – * [[Google Ventures]] – * [[Google WiFi]] – -->
== See also == * [[Criticism of Google]] * [[History of Google]] * [[List of acquisitions by Google]] * [[Google (verb)]] * [[Google Account]] * [[Google bomb]] * [[Google logo]] * [[Google platform]] * [[Google X Lab]] * [[Google.org]] * [[Googleplex]] * [[Google's hoaxes]] * [[Googlewhack]]

All countries, with the exception of Bosnia and Herzegovina, have a single national postal service. ==Africa== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- bgcolor="#cccccc" ! Country !! Company !! Website !! '''[[Egypt]]''' || [[Egypt Post]] || [http://www.egyptpost.org egyptpost.org] |- | '''[[Eritrea]]''' || [[Eritrean Postal Service]] || [http://www.eriposta.com/ eriposta.com] |- | '''[[Ethiopia]]''' || [[Ethiopian Postal Service]] || [http://www.ethiopostal.com/ ethiopostal.com] |- | '''[[Gabon]]''' || [[Gabon Poste]] || [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304044307/http://www.laposte.ga/ ghanapost.com.gh] |- | '''[[Guinea]]''' || [[Office de la poste guinéenne]] || |- | '''[[Guinea-Bissau]]''' || [[Correios da Guiné-Bissau]] || |- | '''[[Kenya]]''' || [[Postal Corporation of Kenya]] || [http://www.posta.co.ke/ posta.co.ke] |- | '''[[Lesotho]]''' || [[Lesotho Post]] || [http://lesothopost.org.ls/ lesothopost.org.ls] |- | '''[[Liberia]]''' || [[Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications (Liberia)]] || [http://www.mopt.gov.lr/ mopt.gov.lr] |- | '''[[Libya]]''' || [[General Posts and Telecommunications Company]] || [http://libyapost.ly/en/ libyapost.ly] |- | '''[[Madagascar]]''' || [[Paositra Malagasy]] || [http://www.paositra.mg/ paositra.mg] |- | '''[[Malawi]]''' || [[Malawi Posts Corporation]] || [http://www.malawiposts.com/ malawiposts.com] |- | revision.text:
The '''Middle Eastern Geodatabase for Antiquities''' (MEGA) is a [[web based]] [[geographic information system]] or GIS developed by the [[Getty Conservation Institute]] (GCI), with matching funds from the [[World Monuments Fund (WMF)]] and in partnership with the Jordanian Department of Antiquities (DoA). The GIS will serve as the primary tool for the Jordanian DoA in its ongoing work to inventory, monitor, and manage Jordan's vast number of archaeological sites.<ref>{{cite news |author=Randy Kennedy |coauthors= |title=In History-Rich Region, a Very New System Tracks Very Old Things |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/25/arts/design/25getty.html?8dpc |quote= |work=[[New York Times]] |date= August 24, 2010 |accessdate=2010-08-25 }}</ref>
== The system ==
MEGA–Jordan is, at its core, an electronic inventory capable of maintaining information on site location and extent, site characteristics, and site condition in an easy-to-use manner. Ultimately it will help standardize and centralize information on archaeological sites throughout the country in a single system focused primarily on the aims of heritage management and research. MEGA–Jordan will become the DoA's preeminent planning and decision-making tool, addressing its needs and demands related to the legal protection of sites, site management, infrastructure and development control, World Heritage requirements, and development of national and regional research strategies. Infrastructure and development planning are especially crucial, and the GIS will permit the DoA to assess the potential impact of development projects (e.g., construction of buildings, roadways, pipelines) on or near archaeological sites. MEGA–Jordan is also seen as a tool for coordinating archaeological site data with Jordanian government ministries (e.g., Tourism and Antiquities, Planning, Agriculture) and for academic research.
The system offers various levels of user access based on user roles—i.e., some users will have full access to all data and the ability to add and edit sites and their attributes, approve new sites, run administrative reports, and export data, while others may only have access to search and view the data.
The MEGA system was built by [http://www.fargeo.com/ Farallon Geographics] using [[open source software]], which means that its software code is not exclusively owned. This allows it to be updated, modified, and customized to meet future needs at little or no cost. It is fully compatible with all standard GIS tools, facilitating data sharing among government agencies and researchers. The core MEGA software has been designed so that it can, independent of the Jordanian system, be freely and readily customized for use by other countries. The system uses such open source technologies as PostgreSQL, PostGIS, GeoServer, OpenLayers, jQuery, and ExtJS.
== Fundamental design requirements ==
# The system should be a map-based, Web-enabled inventory with access to data from all of DoA's regional officess. # It should have a user interface in both English and standard Arabic and be capable of handling data in both languages. # The technical tools (i.e., software) used to build the system must be low-cost (or no-cost wherever feasible), open source, non-proprietary, and accessible both technically and financially by those who will need to support, maintain, and sustain the system for many years to come. # The system must be easy to use and not require extensive training for the general user—i.e., users need not be GIS experts. # It must have wide compatibility with similar systems of Jordanian national and local authorities, such as the Lands and Survey Department, city governments, and the like. # The system must allow the export of data that is fully compatible with other GIS tools such as Google Earth™, [[QGIS]], and ESRI's ArcView. # The system must include the ability to record detailed data on monitoring of sites and site elements and archaeological surveys. # It should be readily customizable to accommodate changes in practices that the DoA may make in the future. # It must ensure, wherever possible, consistent and valid entry of information. # It must provide the ability to prepare data electronically from the field. # The system must include easy, instant reporting capabilities. # All data must be secure and appropriate back-up strategies need to be implemented. # The system should provide various levels of user access based on user roles—i.e., some users will have full access to all data, while others may only have read-access to certain areas of the database. # The system must be developed in such a way that the addition of tools to inventory, monitor, and help manage heritage buildings can be added without major redevelopment of the system.
== Awards == [[File:Al Khazneh Petra.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Al_Khazneh Petra Jordan.|The most iconic image of an archaeological site in Jordan is likely that of Al-Khazneh (Arabic for 'treasury') of Petra, which was elaborately carved into a sandstone cliff between approximately 100 AD and 200 BC. Its name is a misnomer, as the facade's extensive funerary symbols suggest that it was constructed as a tomb.]]
The MEGA system was selected as "one of the 100 most significant innovations of 2010" by Netexplorateur:<ref>[http://www.netexplorateur.org/ Netexplorateur]</ref> "The Netexplorateur 100 is a pragmatic approach to the global digital revolution, based on the power of example. ''The selection recognizes 100 pioneers who produce mobile applications, web 2.0 sites, software or games, break new ground in culture or education, think up new forms of solidarity or citizenship or transform management methods and business models. These 100 Netexplrateurs are exploring new territories and creating new practices to map out and shape the digital era.''"
==See also== *[[Architectural conservation]] *[[Cultural heritage management]] *[[GIS in archaeology]] *[[Historic preservation]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *Access [http://megajordan.org megajordan.org] for viewing only. *Watch a [https://web.archive.org/web/20100713201227/https://www.getty.edu/conservation/publications/videos/project_videos.html video overview of the system.]
[[Category:Archaeology of the Near East]] [[Category:Geographic information systems]]
