revision.text:
{{coord|37.872637|-122.264502|display=title}} {{Infobox University |name = University of California, Berkeley College of Natural Resources |image_name =Cnr_logo.png |image_size= 200px |established = 1868<ref name=history>[http://www.cnr.berkeley.edu/site/history_mission.php Mission and History] - University of California, Berkeley College of Natural Resources</ref> |type = [[Public university|Public]] Professional School |city = [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]] |state = [[California]] |country = U.S. |website = {{url|www.cnr.berkeley.edu}} |dean = J. Keith Gilless <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnr.berkeley.edu/site/deans_office.php|title=Dean's Office Staff|last=UC Berkeley College of Natural Resources|publisher=University of California, Berkeley|accessdate=25 December 2013}}</ref> |undergrad=1,700|postgrad=300|former_names=College of Agriculture|academic_staff=120|parent=University of California, Berkeley}}
The '''College of Natural Resources''' ('''CNR'''), a college of the [[University of California, Berkeley]], is the oldest college in the UC system and home to several internationally top-ranked programs. CNR is considered to be one of the most prestigious schools in Agricultural Economics in the world, ranking #1 according to the Journal of Agricultural and Applied Economics,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://ageconsearch.umn.edu/bitstream/31446/1/23020194.pdf|title=Ranking Agricultural Economics Departments by AJAE Page Counts: A Reappraisal|last=Kinnucan|first=Henry|date=1994|website=Journal of Agricultural and Applied Economics|publisher=Agricultural and Resource Economics Review|access-date=}}</ref> #1 by the Chronicle of Higher Education,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://chronicle.com/article/NRC-Rankings-Overview-/124699|title=Doctoral Programs by the Numbers|date=2010-09-30|newspaper=The Chronicle of Higher Education|issn=0009-5982|access-date=2016-06-03}}</ref> #1 by Perry for its Ph.D. programs and in International Trade,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://down.cenet.org.cn/upfile/52/2007427221351157.pdf|title=Ranking M.S. and Ph.D. Programs in Agricultural Economics – Spring 2004|last=Perry|first=George|date=2004|website=|publisher=Oregon State University|access-date=}}</ref> #1 by the [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]] in Agricultural & Resource Economics,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phds.org/rankings/agricultural-economics|title=Agricultural and Resource Economics Rankings - PhDs.org Graduate School Guide|website=www.phds.org|access-date=2016-06-03}}</ref> and #1 by [[U.S. News & World Report|U.S. News]] in Environmental/Environmental Health.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-education-schools/edu-rankings|title=The Best Education Schools in America, Ranked|website=grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com|access-date=2016-06-03}}</ref> In environmental disciplines, QS World Rankings recognizes the University of California, Berkeley, as the world's leading university in Environmental Studies<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/university-subject-rankings/2016/environmental-studies#sorting=rank+region=+country=+faculty=+stars=false+search=|title=QS World University Rankings by Subject 2016 - Environmental Sciences|date=2016-03-17|website=Top Universities|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> with 100 points in Academic Reputation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/universities/university-california-berkeley-ucb|title=University of California, Berkeley (UCB)|date=2015-07-16|website=Top Universities|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> U.S. News also ranks it as the best global university for environment and ecology.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/best-global-universities/environment-ecology|title=Top Environment/Ecology Universities in the World {{!}} US News Best Global Universities|website=www.usnews.com|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> A study of [[American Journal of Agricultural Economics|AJAE]] authors and their university affiliations found it to have the highest number of pages per research faculty member.<ref name=":0" />
Established in 1868 as the College of Agriculture under the federal [[Morrill Land-Grant Acts]], CNR is the first state-run [[Agricultural experiment station|Agricultural Experiment Station]]. The college is home to four academic departments: Agriculture and Resource Economics; Environmental Science, Policy, and Management; Nutritional Sciences and Toxicology; and Plant and Microbial Biology, and one interdisciplinary program, Energy and Resources Group. Faculty include 40 [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright Fellows]], 29 [[American Association for the Advancement of Science|American Association for the Advancement of Science Fellows]], 16 [[National Academy of Sciences]] members, 12 [[Guggenheim Fellowship|Guggenheim Fellows]], 8 [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] members, 7 [[MacArthur Fellows Program|MacArthur Fellows]], 4 [[List of Nobel laureates|Nobel Laureates]], 2 [[Wolf Prize]] winners, and 2 [[World Food Prize]] winners.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nature.berkeley.edu/about|title=About|website=UC Berkeley College of Natural Resources|access-date=2016-06-03}}</ref>
== History == Plans for the creation of this public university were first developed at the 1849 [[Constitutional Convention (United States)|Constitutional Convention]], but when the State of [[California]] was established in 1850, it lacked the funds necessary to create such a school. Missionaries sent west by the [[American Home Missionary Society|Home Mission Society]] of New York, however, created the [[College of California]] and eventually transferred its ownership to the State in 1855.
By 1862, the State had secured the land necessary to establish a college as a result of the [[Morrill Land-Grant Acts|Morrill Act.]] This college was known as the Agricultural Mining and Mechanical Arts College, and opened formally in 1866.
On March 23, 1868, [[Henry Huntly Haight|Governor H.H. Haight]] combined the resources of this college with the College of California to create the first [[University of California]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://history.library.ucsf.edu/daniel_gilman.html|title=Daniel Coit Gilman and the Early Years of UC - Special Topics - A History of UCSF|website=history.library.ucsf.edu|access-date=2016-06-03}}</ref>
The Board of Regents began admitting women to the University of California in 1871, and the first woman to graduate was Rosa L. Scrivner, with a [[Bachelor of Philosophy|PhB]] in Agriculture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/graduates00univ/graduates00univ_djvu.txt|title=Full text of "Graduates, 1864-1905. November 1905"|website=www.archive.org|access-date=2016-06-03}}</ref> [[File:Cnr campus.png|thumb|Wellman Hall, flanked by Giannini and Hilgard Halls.]]
== Campus == [[File:Cnr map.png|thumb|The original College of Agriculture consisted of the Hilgard, Wellman, and Giannini halls. Today, CNR has expanded to occupy the Koshland, Morgan, and Mulford buildings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nature.berkeley.edu/site/forms/pdf/CNR_Report.pdf|title=College of Natural Resources|last=|first=|date=February 2016|website=Forms & Petitions|publisher=University of California, Berkeley|access-date=}}</ref>]] The College of Natural Resources is located on the northwest end of the UC Berkeley campus, and comprises six main buildings.
These include the historic group of Wellman, Hilgard, and Giannini halls that composed the original college. This trio, known as the Agriculture Complex, is the most unified grouping of buildings on campus.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Riggs|first=William|last2=Knapp|first2=Frederic|date=2012-01-01|title=Hilgard Hall (John Galen Howard) Historic Structures Report|url=https://works.bepress.com/williamriggs/15/}}</ref> They are on the [[National Register of Historic Places]], and are visually unified by a Mediterranean landscape of olive and stone pine trees.
The first hall, Wellman, is a Classical Revival building designed in 1912 by [[John Galen Howard]] and named after [[Harry R. Wellman]], a professor of Agricultural Economics, and acting president of the University.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://texts.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb7t1nb4v2&doc.view=frames&chunk.id=div00071&toc.id=|title=University of California: In Memoriam, 1997|website=texts.cdlib.org|access-date=2016-06-03}}</ref>
Hilgard was constructed six years later by the same architect, and named after [[Eugene W. Hilgard]], professor of Agricultural Chemistry and father of modern soil science. Its neo-classical design is inscribed with the phrase "''To Rescue for Human Society the Native Values of Rural Life''."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://noehill.com/alameda/nat1982004647.asp|title=National Register #82004647: Hilgard Hall on UC Berkeley Campus, California|website=noehill.com|access-date=2016-06-03}}</ref>
Giannini Hall was designed by Howard's co-worker, William Charles Hays, through an endowment from the Bancitaly Corporation (now known as [[Bank of America]]) in memory of their founder, [[Amadeo Giannini]].
==Departments== # '''[https://are.berkeley.edu/ Agricultural and Resource Economics (ARE)]''' researches global food production, nutrition and health, development economics, climate change, [[environmental economics]], applied econometrics, policy evaluation, energy economics, natural resource economics, and international trade.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://are.berkeley.edu/about|title=About|website=Department of Agricultural & Resource Economics {{!}} University of California, Berkeley|access-date=2016-06-03}}</ref> Admissions to ARE's graduate program are highly competitive, with an acceptance rate of 8.8%.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://are.berkeley.edu/graduate-program/frequently-asked-questions|title=Frequently Asked Questions|website=Department of Agricultural & Resource Economics {{!}} University of California, Berkeley|access-date=2016-06-03}}</ref> ARE offers one undergraduate major, [[Bachelor of Science]] (B.S.) in Environmental Economics and Policy (EEP). Admissions to EEP are capped.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://opa.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/CappedMajorAnalysis.pdf|title=Enrollment Trends in Capped Majors|last=|first=|date=|website=Office of Planning & Analysis|publisher=University of California, Berkeley|access-date=}}</ref> ARE is chaired by David Sunding. #'''[https://ourenvironment.berkeley.edu/ Environmental Science, Policy & Management (ESPM)]''' is the largest department with the College of Natural Resources, with three interrelated divisions Ecosystems Sciences, Organisms and Environment, and Society and Environment divisions. Research, teaching and outreach themes include biosphere/critical zone, biodiversity/dynamic environments, stewardship and environmental changes, and humanity and future earth. Admissions to ESPM's graduate program are highly competitive, with an acceptance rate of 8.75%.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ourenvironment.berkeley.edu/graduate-programs/faq|title={{!}} Our Environment at Berkeley|website=Our Environment at Berkeley|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> ESPM graduates may earn a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in Environmental Science, Policy, and Management, a [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in Forestry, or a [[Master of Science|M.S.]] in Range Management. ESPM also offers five undergraduate majors: Conservation and Resource Studies (CRS), Environmental Sciences (ES), Forestry and Natural Resources (FNR), Molecular Environmental Biology (MEB), and Society and Environment (SE).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ourenvironment.berkeley.edu/undergraduate-programs|title={{!}} Our Environment at Berkeley|website=Our Environment at Berkeley|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> ESPM is chaired by George Roderick. # '''[https://nst.berkeley.edu/ Nutritional Sciences & Toxicology (NST)]''' researches the function of nutrients, phytochemicals, toxicants, and the metabolic interaction of these elements in living organisms in order to inform recommendations for dietary patterns to achieve optimum health and the treatment or prevent of chronic disease conditions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nst.berkeley.edu/graduate|title=Graduate Program|website=Nutritional Sciences & Toxicology {{!}} University of California, Berkeley|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> NST offers doctoral degrees in Molecular and Biochemical Nutrition, as well as in Molecular Toxicology. The department oversees one undergraduate major program in Nutritional Sciences, with specialized tracks in Physiology & Metabolism, Dietetics, and Molecular Toxicology.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nst.berkeley.edu/undergraduate|title=Undergraduate Program|website=Nutritional Sciences & Toxicology {{!}} University of California, Berkeley|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> NST is chaired by Andreas Stahl. # '''[http://plantandmicrobiology.berkeley.edu/ Plant and Microbial Biology]''' encompasses theoretical and applied research in ecology, computational biology, genomics, host-microbe interactions, physiology, and biochemistry. It offers a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in Plant or Microbial Biology, and oversees two similarly named undergraduate major programs. PMB is chaired by Kris Niyogi. # '''[https://erg.berkeley.edu Energy and Resources Group (ERG)]''' provides education and research for a sustainable environment and a just society. ERG is a collaborative community of graduate students, core faculty, over 100 affiliated faculty and researchers across the campus, and nearly 500 alumni across the globe. Degrees include MA, MS, and PhD. Beginning in the 2017-18 academic year, ERG is chaired by Dan Kammen.
== Research ==
=== Centers === * Berkeley Food Institute * Berkeley Water Center * Center for Diversified Farming Systems * Center for Effective Global Action * Center for Fire Research and Outreach * Center for Forestry * Center for Green Chemistry * Center for Weight and Health * Energy Biosciences Institute * Plant Gene Expression Center
=== Facilities === * Biological Imaging Facility * Geospatial Innovation Facility * Gill Tract * Inductively Coupled Plasma Spectroscopy Facility * Oxford Facility Unit
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.cnr.berkeley.edu/}}
{{University of California, Berkeley}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox river | name = Vizelj
Визељ | image = Kanal-vizelj-ciscenje01.jpg | image_caption = Kayaking on the Vizelj | source1_location = north of [[Padinska Skela]], [[Serbia]] | mouth_location = [[Danube]], at [[Krnjača]], [[Serbia]] | mouth_coordinates = {{coord|44.833917|N|20.470393|E|display=it|region:RS_type:river_source:GNS-enwiki}} | progression = {{RDanube}} | subdivision_type1 = Country | subdivision_name1 = [[Serbia]] | length = {{convert|31|km|abbr=on}} | source1_elevation = | discharge1_avg = | basin_size = }} The '''Vizelj''' ({{lang-sr|Визељ}}) is a short channeled river in north-central [[Serbia]], the left tributary to the [[Danube]]. During its entire flow it runs through the suburban section of [[Belgrade]], on the territory of municipality of [[Palilula, Belgrade|Palilula]]. == Course and geography == [[Image: Labudovi-vizelj-2016.jpg|right|thumb|240px|Swans on the Vizelj]] Vizelj originates north of [[Padinska Skela]], in the central part of the [[Pančevački Rit]], a former marshland in the southwestern corner of the [[Banat]] region. The course of the river is in the north-to-south direction and is generally full of curves and meanders. It flows through Padinska Skela and [[Kovilovo]], before it is being crossed by the Northern Tangent, in wider sense, a northern part of the [[Belgrade bypass]]. From there, meandering in the east-west direction, it flows on the west border of the urbanized area of [[Borča]] (neighborhoods of [[Mali Zbeg]], [[Nova Borča]] and [[Stara Borča]]). After exiting Borča, it receives the western section of the channeled streams of [[Sebeš|Mokri Sebeš]] from the left and Veliki Kanal from the right side, crosses the embankment which protects the inland from the Danube and turns to the southeast. Flowing on the southern border of the neighborhood of [[Kotež]], it empties into the Danube at its {{convert|1,168.5|km|abbr=on}}. It forms the entire eastern border of the ''[[river island|ada]]'' of [[Kožara]], and that entire section is projected as the future much larger [[Čaplja]] island. The final {{convert|2|km|abbr=on}} of Vizelj are also known as the ''Jojkićev Dunavac'', named after the former [[mayor of Belgrade]] [[Đurica Jojkić]], as during his tenure that section was channel and widened in an effort to quicken the drainage of the Pančevački Rit. Weekend settlement [[Mika Alas]] is located at the very confluence of the Vizelj.{{cite book |title=Beograd - plan i vodič |date=1999 |publisher=Geokarta |isbn=86-459-0006-8}}{{cite book|title=Beograd - plan grada|date=2006|publisher=M@gic M@p|isbn=86-83501-53-1}}{{cite book|title=Turističko područje Beograda|date=2007|author=|publisher=Geokarta|isbn=86-459-0099-8}}{{cite web|url= http://www.plovidba.info/forum/saveti-i-uputstva/ono-sto-znamo-i-ne-znamo-o-dunavu/ |author= |title= Ono što znamo i ne znamo o Dunavu |date=20 August 2009 |publisher=Plovidba info|language=Serbian}} The length of the Vizelj, due to the channeling and artificial connections with the surrounding channels, has been reported as either {{convert|27|km|abbr=on}} or {{convert|31|km|abbr=on}}. The average width of the stream is {{convert|50|m|abbr=on}} and is {{convert|1.5|to|2|m|abbr=on}} deep.{{Citation | last = | first = | author = Nikola Belić | title = Kanal VIzelj će biti kajakaška oaza | newspaper = [[Politika]] | pages = | language = Serbian | date = 21 August 2012 | url = }} During the normal and high water levels, smaller vessels can enter the channel, but during the low waters it is inaccessible. However, it is used for kayaking since 1972, when the first kayak club in Borča was founded.{{cite web|url= http://www.blic.rs/vesti/beograd/neverovatna-slika-u-borci-zabeleo-se-kanal/1knl8ev |author=Č.L.|title= Neverovatna slika u Borči: Zabeleo se kanal |date=26 March 2016| publisher= [[Blic]]|language=Serbian}} == Human history == [[Image: Vizelj park.jpg |right|thumb|240px|[[Vizelj Park]], in the vicinity of the river]] Initial works on the river were done in the 18th century, during the reign of the empress [[Maria Theresa]], as the area was ruled by [[Austria]] at the time. In the early 1960s, with the digging of the ''Jojkićev Dunavac'', the stream was extended and got its present form. As the area became rapidly urbanized after the [[World War II]], which was not followed by the adequate communal infrastructure, the Vizelj got more and more polluted. It was partially cleaned in 2009. In 2012 sisters [[Nikolina Moldovan]] and [[Olivera Moldovan]], who practiced on the Vizelj, petitioned to the mayor [[Dragan Đilas]] to do something about the worsening conditions of the river as it is important for the national sport. City decided to financially support the cleaning, though that is not administratively under the city jurisdiction. In August–September 2012 the stream was dredged, cleaned and the vegetation was cut. Yearly kayaking [[regattas]] have been organized since then. In 2014 the channel was cleaned again but by May 2015 it was again covered in vegetation and turned into the morass.{{cite web|url= http://www.blic.rs/vesti/beograd/na-njih-niko-ne-misli-ocajni-uslovi-u-kojima-treniraju-kajakasi-iz-borce/snyqnh3 |author=Marija Kosanović |title= Očajni uslovi u kojima treniraju kajakaši iz Borče |date=31 May 2015| publisher= [[Blic]]|language=Serbian}} The river was cleaned during the summer of 2015.{{cite web|url= http://www.koreni.rs/oaza-mira-i-prirode-koju-su-svi-zaboravili/ |author= |title= Oaza mira i prirode koju su svi zaboravili |date=1 December 2015| publisher= Koreni |language=Serbian}} Since then, locals and members of the kayaк clubs organized and regularly clean the stream, including the cleaning of the banks in April 2017.{{cite web|url= http://www.oplanetise.com/2017/04/22/uredjenje-obale-kanala-vizelj-u-borci/|author= |title= Uređenje obale kanala Vizelj u Borči |date=22 April 2017 | publisher= Zelena lista Srbije |language=Serbian}} In April 2014, during the repair of the waste water collector, toxic substances were poured into the river which caused a massive [[fish kill]].{{cite web|url= http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/beograd.74.html:488186-Pomor-ribe-u-borcanskom-kanalu-Vizelj |author=M.Lj.Ppopović |title= Pomor ribe u borčanskom kanalu Vizelj |date=21 April 2014| publisher= [[Večernje Novosti]]|language=Serbian}} In August 2014, the agricultural company PKB apparently discharged large amounts of [[ammonia]] into the Vizelj which nearly killed the entire fish population.{{cite web|url= http://www.blic.rs/vesti/beograd/mrtve-ribe-ponovo-plutaju-po-vizelju/cdkw015 |author=M. Jovićević |title= Mrtve ribe ponovo plutaju po Vizelju |date=4 August 2014| publisher= [[Blic]]|language=Serbian}}{{cite web|url= http://www.blic.rs/vesti/beograd/borcanci-jeli-otrovanu-ribu/5p14f1l |author=Marija Kosanović |title= Borčanci jeli otrovanu ribu?! |date=5 August 2014| publisher= [[Blic]]|language=Serbian}} Despite the pollution, the river is popular among the fishermen, but the recreational fishing is forbidden on the course of {{convert|600|m|abbr=on}}, between river's 3rd and 4th kilometer.{{cite web|url= http://www.srbijasume.rs/rpbeograde.html |author= |title= Fishery area "Belgrade" |date=2016| publisher= Srbijašume |language=}} In the autumn of 2010 a flock of 30 swans landed on the Vizelj and have been coming every years since then, and the number of swans doubled. They became a local attraction. However, the area was plagued by the [[avian influenza]] in January 2017, which killed almost 40 swans.{{cite web|url= http://www.blic.rs/vesti/beograd/pomor-ptica-se-nastavlja-od-pticjeg-gripa-uginulo-39-labudova/wbgm2nr |author= Ana Ristović |title= Od ptičjeg gripa uginulo 39 labudova |date=27 January 2017| publisher= Blic|language=}} Vizelj is name of the PKB's pig farm. Also, a new stadium of the [[FK BSK Borča]], built in the vicinity of the river in 2009, is named [[Vizelj Park]]. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Rivers of Serbia]] [[Category:Geography of Belgrade]]

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=November 2015}} {{Coord|56|27|32|N|9|37|57|E|display=title}}
'''Ø''' is a piece of land in the valley of the [[Nørreå]] in the eastern part of [[Jutland]], [[Denmark]]. Its name means ''[[island]]'' (ø in the [[Danish language]]) and probably comes from the island-like approach to this piece of land, although it is completely landlocked and surrounded by [[meadow]]s.
Ø is famous among [[lexicography|lexicographers]] for the extreme brevity of its name: the single letter [[Ø]].
==See also== *[[List of short place names]]
==Sources==
===Danish sites=== *[http://www.miljo.viborgamt.dk/sw4661.asp Viborg amt's official site on Nørreå] *[http://www.fugleognatur.dk/forum/show_message.asp?MessageID=2470&ForumID=6 The Ø hills on fugleognatur.dk] *[http://www.skovognatur.dk/Ud/Oplev/55/Noerreaadalen.htm Nørreå valley on skovognatur.dk] *[http://palaeo.wikidev.net/Regional_geologi_og_topografi Regional geology and topography]
{{DEFAULTSORT:O, Denmark}} [[Category:Geography of Denmark]]
